Executive Summary



Savage Railport located at Mossville, Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana is required to have a Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  The RMP is required under the provisions of 40 CFR Part 68 (Accidental Release Provisions for Hazardous Chemicals), a.k.a. Risk Management Program (RMP). The PSM Program is required under the provisions in 29 CFR 1910.119.



The purpose of the Risk Management Plan is to identify and prevent the potential accidental release of specific "regulated substances" that have the potential to cause harm to the public and the environment outside the property boundaries.  "Regulated substances" are flammable and toxic chemicals and materials identified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulation codified in Part 68 of Chapter 40 Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR Part 68).  Savage Railport - Mossville, LA has quantities of one "regulated substance" above the 40 CFR Part 68 applicability threshold amount for Flammable Mixtures listed below in Section 2 of this Summary.



The remainder of the Executive Summary is organized as follows:



Section 1: Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 

Section 2: Overview of Regulated Substances 

Section 3: Accidental Release Prevention Program

Section 4: Five-year Accidental Release Summary

Section 5: Emergency Response Program

Section 6: Planned Changes to Improve Safety



1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

 

Equipment at the facility must be designed, operated, and maintained in full compliance with applicable engineering standards, accepted industry codes, or industry standards.  Systems and procedures are in place to control changes in process technology, facilities, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures, in order to provide for continued safe and reliable operations.



All Team Members at the Savage Railport - Mossville, LA have the responsibility to protect the enviro

nment and to ensure the safety and security of his/her fellow workers.  Written policies and standards are in place to ensure:



*    The safety and health of Team Members and other workers at the site;

*    Protection of the environment;

*    Reliable and efficient operation of the facility equipment;

*    Minimization of the risk of product or property losses; and

*    Maintaining a positive relationship with the communities adjacent to the site.



These written policies and standards are described further elsewhere in this document.



2 OVERVIEW OF REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The Savage Railport - Mossville, LA is a specialty railyard operation. Railcars will be received by the railyard and kept until they depart for their final destination.  



RMP-regulated substances to be handled are limited to Liquefied Petroleum Gases (LOG), which is mixtures of Propane and Butane.  No other RMP-regulated flammable or toxic substances are expected to present onsite in quantities exceeding the respective RMP applicability thresholds.  The regulated substances will be found in railcars disconnected from locomotive power.  No blending or processing of the materials will take place at the railyard.



The entire area is classified as a single RMP-regulated process.  This process is qualified as a Program 2 facility per the RMP rule. 



3 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 



The Savage Transportation Management, Inc. Director of Operations has the overall responsibility for the site and utilizes an internal staff of Team Members, combined with environmental, health, and safety consultants to maintain compliance with all aspects of the plant's Risk Management Plan.  In addition, all railyard personnel are trained to be responsible for carrying out their respective duties in a safe manner using established and verified procedures.



Process Safety Information



The Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility maintains technical documents that are used to help ensure safe operations of t

he process units.  Process Safety Information (PSI), which addresses chemical properties and associated hazards; limits for key process parameters; limits for specific chemical inventories; and equipment design and maintenance information are summarized in the documentation maintained in the local office and in the company headquarters.



The PSI is utilized in process unit hazard analyses and in inspection, maintenance, and training activities.  This information is kept current by the application of management of change and pre-startup safety review procedures, which are described further in this document.



This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.



Hazard Review



The Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility conducts hazard review to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled.  Under this program, the process is systematically examined by a multi-disciplinary team to identify hazards that could result in an accidental release of a regulated substance and to ensure that adequate control is in place to manage those hazards.  The Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility utilized the Hazardous Operation (HAZOP) methodology for the facility's first hazard review. Pertinent parameters, such as process parameters, ongoing equipment mechanical integrity/reliability and redundant safety controls were examined. 



In order to help ensure that the process controls or process hazards do not deviate significantly from the original design safety features, Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility will update and revalidate the hazard review every five years.  The RMP Program will be audited for its effectiveness at three-year intervals, as described in the Compliance Auditing section below.



Oper

ating Procedures



The Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility has developed and implemented written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities at the facility.  The written operating procedures address the various modes of process operations, such as unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown and initial startup of a new process.



These procedures are utilized by the experienced operators during training sessions to ensure consistent application by new operators.  The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them to reflect changes made through the management of change process and through annual reviews and certification.



Training



The Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility's operating procedures require personnel to be trained in the safe operation of the facility processes, the use of personal protective equipment (PPE), the management of potential process deviations and emergency response, if required.  Understanding of the process and how to operate the process safely can minimize the potential for unplanned incidents or releases.



Team Members are trained according to the applicable requirements before they are allowed presenting in the area and receive refresher training on the operating procedures associated with the regulated chemical processes annually.



Maintenance



A comprehensive maintenance program requires routine inspection and testing of process equipment, instrumentation, and shipping containers.  Periodic reviews and auditing of the proper implementation of this program requires participation of maintenance, operations, and management staff.  



Compliance Audits



To ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning as intended, the Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility will contract independent auditors at three-year intervals.  The audits include an assessment of the written prevention program elements, ret

ained RMP records (e.g., training records, maintenance records, etc.) and personnel interviews.



Compliance reviews are performed by trained subject matter experts.  Audit results are communicated to respective Team Members and at least the last two reports are retained.  Action items or recommendations resulting from these audits are tracked to completion.



Incident Investigation



The Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility accident investigation program covers four types of incidents:



*    Personal injury;

*    Environmental release;

*    Equipment damage and loss of materials caused by fire, equipment failure, or other circumstance; and

*    Those incidents that could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic event.



The goal of a formal incident investigation process is to determine the root cause associated with a release or near miss and to develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of a similar incident.  The investigation team is directed by a team leader who has had training in incident investigation.



The results of the investigation are communicated to all Team Members.  The Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility will maintain copies of incident investigation reports for a minimum of five years.  Corrective measures and action items resulting from an investigation will be tracked to completion and documented.



Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Critical to the site's prevention programs are the levels of protection intentionally designed into the process.  At the most basic levels, trained operators working with current operating procedures and process safety information maintain the processes in a safe operating condition and in compliance with applicable health, safety and environmental regulations.



Emergency firefighting and spill control equipment is immediately accessible.  Personnel are trained in emergency notification, response, and evacuation procedures.  



4 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Savage Railport - Mossville, LA

Facility is a new facility in 2021 and thus has not had any RMP-reportable accidents.  Information on any reportable accident will be submitted to the EPA as a correction to the RMP within six month after occurrence and completion of a comprehensive investigation of the root cause and recommendations for process improvement.



5 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility personnel will not be primary responders to significant emergencies like large fires.  The Railyard has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) for addressing minor material spills and manageable fires but it will rely on local responders for addressing large accidents.  For this reason, the facility coordinated efforts with local responders and Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility is included in the written community emergency response plan.  



The purpose of the Railyard ERP is to protect workers, the public and the environment from harm due to minor emergencies at the site.  The ERP includes procedures to provide for prompt emergency response to include:



*    First aid and emergency medical treatment;

*    Initial response to emergency incidents such as small fires that can be easily contained, materials releases, and natural disasters such as high winds and electrical storms;

*    Emergency evacuation and rescue;

*    Notification of local, state and federal emergency response agencies and the public, as required; and

*    Post-incident remediation and decontamination.



The emergency response program provides training of all facility staff, which varies in level of detail based on assigned roles and responsibilities.  Routine inspections and annual drills will be conducted to ensure that the program may be effectively implemented.



6 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Savage Railport - Mossville, LA Facility has a comprehensive hazard identification and mitigation program to ensure process safety.  This program includes periodic hazard reviews, investigati

ons of near misses and audits of the process area.  Management will be notified of deficiencies or potential hazards and a mitigation plan will be promptly implemented.



Current plans for future improvements to the operation of the site process include the use of portable air monitoring instruments for flammable vapors.
